title: Introduction to Fractions
subject: Maths
description: Learn what fractions are, types of fractions, how to simplify, and real-life applications.

content.text: A fraction represents a part of a whole. It has two numbers: a numerator (top) and a denominator (bottom).

content.caption: 3/4 of a pizza means 3 slices out of 4 total slices.

content.text: Fractions can be proper (numerator < denominator), improper (numerator > denominator), or mixed (whole number + fraction).

items: Proper fraction: 3/4
Improper fraction: 7/4
Mixed fraction: 1 3/4

content.text: Fractions that represent the same value are called equivalent fractions.
Example: To simplify 8/12, find the GCD (4) and divide numerator and denominator: 8 ÷ 4 = 2, 12 ÷ 4 = 3 → result = 2/3.
To add or subtract fractions, make the denominators the same, then add/subtract the numerators.

items: Find the LCM of denominators
Convert fractions to have same denominator
Add or subtract numerators

content.text: Fractions are used in cooking (1/2 cup sugar), construction (3/8 inch screw), and in sports (batting averages).
Summary: Fractions break a whole into equal parts, can be simplified, and are used in daily life.

items: Q1: Simplify 12/16 → A: 3/4
Q3: Convert 3/2 into a mixed fraction → A: 1 1/2

title: Photosynthesis Basics
subject: Science
description: Understand how plants make food via photosynthesis, its steps, and importance.

content.text: Photosynthesis is the process by which plants use sunlight to produce food (glucose).

content.caption: Animation showing photosynthesis process

content.text: Photosynthesis is the process by which green plants and some bacteria use sunlight, carbon dioxide, and water to produce glucose and oxygen.

items: Carbon dioxide (CO₂) from air
Water (H₂O) from soil
Chlorophyll present in leaves
Sunlight as the energy source

content.text: The process takes place in the chloroplasts, where chlorophyll captures light energy and converts it into chemical energy.

items: Provides oxygen for respiration
Forms the base of the food chain
Removes carbon dioxide from atmosphere

content.text: Rate of photosynthesis depends on light intensity, availability of water, carbon dioxide concentration, and temperature.
Understanding photosynthesis helps in agriculture (greenhouses), reforestation, and even in designing artificial photosynthesis systems for sustainable energy.

items: Q1: Name the gas released during photosynthesis → A: Oxygen
Q2: Where does photosynthesis occur? → A: In the chloroplasts of leaves
Q3: Write the chemical equation → A: 6CO₂ + 6H₂O → C₆H₁₂O₆ + 6O₂

title: Fun With Magnets
subject: Science
description: Fun with Magnets introduces students to the fundamental concepts of magnetism, covering topics such as magnetic poles, magnetic materials, and the behavior of magnets in different situations.

content.caption: Magnets can attract iron objects like pins, nails, and paper clips.

content.text: Magnets are objects that produce a magnetic field, which can attract certain materials like iron, cobalt, and nickel. They have been used since ancient times for navigation and in daily life.
Magnetic materials are attracted by a magnet (iron, nickel, cobalt), while non-magnetic materials (wood, plastic, paper) are not affected. This property helps in separating materials in industries.
A magnet has two poles: North Pole and South Pole. Like poles repel each other, while unlike poles attract. This property is used in making compasses.
The space around a magnet where its force acts is called the magnetic field. Iron filings arrange themselves along invisible magnetic field lines when sprinkled around a magnet.
Magnets can be made by rubbing a piece of iron with a magnet (magnetizing by stroking) or using electricity (electromagnets). This is an exciting activity for students to try.

items: Used in compasses for navigation
Used in electric bells and motors
Found in fridge doors and magnetic locks
Used in separating magnetic materials from waste

content.text: Summary: Magnets are fascinating objects with practical applications in daily life, technology, and industry.

items: Q1: What happens when two North poles are brought together? → A: They repel
Q2: Name two magnetic materials → A: Iron, Nickel

title: Rational Numbers
subject: Maths
description: A rational number is a number that is of the form p/q where p and q are integers and q ≠ 0. The set of rational numbers is denoted by Q.

content.caption: Rational numbers are numbers that can be written as p/q, where q ≠ 0.

content.text: A rational number is any number that can be expressed in the form p/q where p and q are integers and q ≠ 0. The set of rational numbers is denoted by Q. All fractions, some decimals, and all integers are examples of rational numbers.

items: 1/2 (half)
-3/5 (negative rational number)
7 (can be written as 7/1)
0.75 (can be written as 3/4)

content.text: A rational number is said to be in standard form if its denominator is positive and the numerator and denominator have no common factors other than 1.
Example: -6/-8 = 6/8 (make denominator positive), then simplify to 3/4.
Equivalent rational numbers represent the same value. Multiplying or dividing both numerator and denominator by the same non-zero number gives an equivalent rational number.
To compare rational numbers, make their denominators equal (find the LCM) and then compare their numerators.
Example: Compare 3/4 and 5/8. LCM of 4 and 8 = 8. 3/4 = 6/8 and 5/8 = 5/8 → 6/8 > 5/8, so 3/4 > 5/8.
We can add, subtract, multiply, and divide rational numbers using simple rules:

items: Addition/Subtraction: Make denominators same, then add/subtract numerators.
Multiplication: Multiply numerators together and denominators together.
Division: Multiply the first number by the reciprocal of the second.

content.text: Rational numbers are used in sharing (splitting food, money), in measurements (1/2 litre of milk), in finance (interest rates), and in science (ratios and proportions).
Summary: Rational numbers extend our understanding of numbers and help in solving real-world problems involving parts, ratios, and proportions.

items: Q1: Write 0.6 as a rational number → A: 3/5

title: Reproduction in Plants
subject: Science
description: Learn about how plants reproduce – covering sexual reproduction, asexual reproduction, pollination, fertilization, and seed dispersal.

content.caption: Plants reproduce through both sexual and asexual methods.

content.text: Reproduction in plants is the process by which new plants are produced. It ensures the continuation of the species. Plants reproduce both sexually and asexually.
Asexual reproduction does not involve gametes. New plants are produced from vegetative parts like roots, stems, or leaves.

items: Vegetative propagation by roots (e.g., sweet potato)
Vegetative propagation by stems (e.g., money plant, rose)
Cuttings, layering, grafting used in horticulture

content.text: Sexual reproduction in plants involves the formation of male and female gametes, pollination, fertilization, and the development of seeds and fruits.
Pollination is the transfer of pollen grains from the anther (male part) to the stigma (female part) of a flower. It can be self-pollination or cross-pollination.
After pollination, the male gamete fuses with the female gamete to form a zygote, which develops into an embryo. The ovule becomes a seed, and the ovary becomes a fruit.
Seeds are dispersed by wind, water, animals, and explosive mechanisms to reduce competition and help plants spread to new places.
Summary: Plant reproduction is crucial for maintaining biodiversity and food production.

items: Q1: Name two modes of asexual reproduction → A: Cutting and Grafting
Q2: What is pollination? → A: Transfer of pollen from anther to stigma

title: Decimals
subject: Maths
description: Learn what decimals are, place value of decimal digits, and how to perform operations like addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division with decimals.

content.caption: Decimals help represent numbers between whole numbers on the number line.

content.text: A decimal number is a number that uses a decimal point to show a value less than 1. It is another way to write fractions with denominators like 10, 100, or 1000.
The first digit after the decimal is tenths, the next is hundredths, then thousandths, and so on.

items: 0.5 → 5 tenths
0.25 → 2 tenths, 5 hundredths
1.234 → 1 whole, 2 tenths, 3 hundredths, 4 thousandths

content.text: Compare decimals by looking at digits from left to right. Add zeros if needed to make lengths equal.
Example: Compare 0.5 and 0.45 → 0.50 > 0.45 so 0.5 is greater.

items: Addition: Line up decimal points, then add normally.
Subtraction: Line up decimal points, subtract normally.
Multiplication: Ignore decimal points, multiply numbers, then put decimal in result.
Division: Move decimal point in divisor to make it whole, move dividend's decimal same steps, then divide.

content.text: Write decimal as a fraction with denominator 10, 100, or 1000 depending on decimal places, then simplify.
Decimals are used in money (₹5.50), measurements (2.75 m), and science (1.23 g).
Summary: Decimals make it easy to work with numbers between whole numbers, especially in practical situations.

items: Q1: Convert 0.75 into a fraction → A: 3/4
Q3: Which is greater: 0.6 or 0.56? → A: 0.6

title: Irrational Numbers
subject: Maths
description: Learn about irrational numbers, their properties, representation on the number line, and examples like √2, π, and more.

content.caption: Irrational numbers cannot be expressed as a fraction p/q with integers p and q.

content.text: Irrational numbers are real numbers that cannot be expressed as p/q where p and q are integers and q ≠ 0. Their decimal expansion is non-terminating and non-repeating.

items: √2, √3, √5 (non-perfect square roots)
e (Euler’s number ≈ 2.718…)
They cannot be written as terminating or repeating decimals.
Sum/product of a rational and an irrational number is irrational (except special cases like 2 + (-2)).
Their squares can be rational (example: (√2)² = 2).

content.text: Irrational numbers can be represented on the number line using geometric construction. For example, to represent √2, construct a right-angled triangle with both legs = 1 unit. The hypotenuse is √2.
Difference Between Rational and Irrational Numbers

items: Rational numbers can be expressed as p/q, irrational numbers cannot.
Rational numbers have terminating or repeating decimals, irrational numbers do not.
Q1: Is √9 irrational? → A: No, √9 = 3 which is rational.
Q2: Represent √3 on the number line. → A: Construct right triangle with legs 1 and √2, hypotenuse = √3.
Q3: Is 0.333... irrational? → A: No, it is rational because it can be written as 1/3.

title: Motion
subject: Science
description: Learn about motion, types of motion, speed, velocity, acceleration, and graphical representation of motion.

content.caption: Motion is the change in position of an object with respect to time.

content.text: Motion is said to occur when an object changes its position with respect to a reference point and time.

items: Translatory Motion (straight-line motion)
Rotational Motion (about an axis)
Oscillatory Motion (back and forth motion)

content.text: Speed is the distance travelled per unit time. Velocity is speed in a particular direction. Velocity can be positive or negative depending on direction.
Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity with respect to time. It can be uniform or non-uniform.
Formula: a = (v - u)/t where u = initial velocity, v = final velocity, t = time taken.
Distance-time and velocity-time graphs help in analyzing motion. The slope of a distance-time graph gives speed. The area under a velocity-time graph gives distance travelled.

items: v = u + at
s = ut + ½at²
v² = u² + 2as
Q1: An object moves 20 m in 4 seconds. Find its speed. → A: Speed = Distance/Time = 20/4 = 5 m/s.
Q2: A car's velocity changes from 10 m/s to 20 m/s in 5 seconds. Find its acceleration. → A: a = (20-10)/5 = 2 m/s²
Q3: Name three types of motion. → A: Translatory, Rotational, Oscillatory.

title: Knowing Our Numbers
subject: Maths
description: Learn about large numbers, place value, comparison of numbers, and estimating sums and differences.

content.caption: Numbers can be represented in place value form.

content.text: Numbers are the foundation of mathematics. They allow us to count objects, compare quantities, and measure values in real life. Large numbers often appear in population counts, distances in kilometres, or currency in lakhs and crores.

The place of a digit in a number determines its value. For example, in 3,245 → 3 is in the thousands place, 2 in the hundreds place, 4 in the tens place, and 5 in the ones place. India follows the Indian Place Value System (ones, tens, hundreds, thousands, lakhs, crores), while the International System uses millions and billions.

To compare numbers, we first count the digits. The number with more digits is greater. If the digits are equal, we compare digit by digit from left to right. Example: 95,426 > 92,315 since the first two digits (95 vs 92) differ.
Estimation helps us in quick calculations. Rounding off numbers to the nearest 10, 100, or 1000 makes it easier to add, subtract, or multiply. Example: 4,738 rounded to the nearest hundred is 4,700.
Large numbers are used in population census, measuring distances between cities, or handling financial transactions involving lakhs and crores.

items:
Q1: Write the number name for 5,43,217 in the Indian system. 
Ans: Five lakh forty-three thousand two hundred seventeen.

Q2: Round off 6,452 to the nearest hundred. 
Ans: 6,500.

Q3: Which is greater: 9,87,432 or 98,743? 
Ans: 9,87,432 (since it has 6 digits compared to 5).

title: Mensuration
subject: Maths
description: Mensuration deals with measurement of shapes, including perimeter and area of plane figures.

content.caption: Mensuration helps us find perimeter and area of shapes.

content.text: Mensuration is the branch of mathematics that deals with measurement of lengths, areas, and volumes of 2D and 3D shapes. It is widely used in real life for construction, land measurement, and design.
Perimeter is the total length of the boundary of a figure. Example: Perimeter of rectangle = 2 × (length + breadth). Perimeter of a square = 4 × side.
Area is the space enclosed within the boundary of a figure. Examples: Area of a rectangle = length × breadth; Area of a triangle = 1/2 × base × height.
Perimeter is expressed in linear units (cm, m). Area is expressed in square units (cm², m²). Volume of solids is measured in cubic units (cm³, m³).
Mensuration is applied in fencing fields, tiling floors, measuring land area, and determining the capacity of tanks.

items:
Q1: Find the perimeter of a square of side 15 cm. 
Ans: 4 × 15 = 60 cm.

Q2: Find the area of a rectangle with length 20 m and breadth 15 m. 
Ans: 20 × 15 = 300 m².

Q3: A triangular park has base 50 m and height 40 m. Find its area. 
Ans: 1/2 × 50 × 40 = 1000 m².

title: Fibre to Fabric
subject: Science
description: Learn how fibres are obtained from plants and animals, and how they are converted into fabric.

content.caption: Fibres are spun into yarn and woven into fabric.

content.text: Fibres are thin strands that can be spun into yarn and woven into fabric. They can be natural (from plants and animals) or synthetic (made in factories).
Cotton is obtained from cotton plants, especially from the fruit (bolls). Jute is obtained from the stem of jute plants. These fibres are cleaned, combed, and spun into yarn.
Wool is obtained from sheep, goat, and camel hair. Silk is obtained from silkworm cocoons. These fibres are soft, warm, and lustrous.
Fibres are spun into yarns, which are then woven or knitted into fabrics. Traditional looms and modern machines are used for weaving.
Fabrics are used in making clothes, upholstery, curtains, and industrial materials.

items:
Q1: Name two plant fibres and two animal fibres. 
Ans: Cotton, Jute (plant); Wool, Silk (animal).

Q2: From which part of the plant do we get jute? 
Ans: From the stem of jute plants.

Q3: Why is silk considered luxurious? 
Ans: It is shiny, smooth, and comfortable to wear.

title: Motion and Measurement of Distances
subject: Science
description: Introduction to motion, measurement of distance, units of measurement, and history of transport.

content.caption: Motion and measurement help us understand movement and distances.

content.text: Motion is the change in position of an object with time. Examples include a moving car, a swinging pendulum, and a spinning wheel.
Different objects exhibit different motions: Linear (car moving on road), Circular (hands of a clock), Periodic (swing of a pendulum), and Rotational (spinning top).
Distances can be measured using rulers, metre scales, measuring tapes, or electronic devices. For large distances, kilometres are used.
To avoid confusion, scientists agreed on SI units. The SI unit of length is metre (m). 100 cm = 1 m, and 1000 m = 1 km.
Transport evolved from walking and bullock carts to bicycles, trains, cars, and airplanes. Better understanding of motion and distance measurement helped in this progress.

items:
Q1: Name the SI unit of length. 
Ans: Metre (m).

Q2: Give an example of periodic motion. 
Ans: Swinging of a pendulum.

Q3: How many metres are there in 5 km? 
Ans: 5 × 1000 = 5000 metres.

title: Simple Equations
subject: Maths
description: Learn how to form and solve simple linear equations with one variable.

content.caption: Equations maintain balance between two sides.

content.text: An equation is a mathematical statement where two expressions are equal. It usually contains a variable (like x) whose value we need to find.
Equations are formed from word problems. Example: 'A number increased by 5 is 9' → x + 5 = 9.
We solve equations by performing opposite operations on both sides to isolate the variable. Example: x + 5 = 9 → x = 9 - 5 = 4.
Think of an equation as a weighing scale. To keep balance, whatever is done to one side must also be done to the other.
Equations are used in real life to solve problems involving ages, money, distances, and measurements.

items:
Q2: A number multiplied by 3 gives 18. Find the number. 
Ans: Let number = x. Equation: 3x = 18 → x = 6.

Q3: If 2x - 5 = 9, find x. 
Ans: 2x = 14 → x = 7.

Q4: The sum of a number and twice the number is 36. Find the number. 
Ans: Let number = x. Equation: x + 2x = 36 → 3x = 36 → x = 12.

title: Perimeter and Area
subject: Maths
description: Learn formulas to calculate the perimeter and area of various 2D shapes.

content.caption: Perimeter measures boundary; area measures space inside.

content.text: Perimeter is the distance around a figure, while area is the surface enclosed within it. Both are essential in daily life applications like fencing land or tiling floors.
Square = 4 × side; Rectangle = 2 × (l + b); Triangle = sum of three sides; Circle = 2πr.
Square = side²; Rectangle = length × breadth; Triangle = 1/2 × base × height; Circle = πr².
Perimeter is expressed in units (cm, m), while area is in square units (cm², m²).
Used in fencing gardens, calculating cost of flooring, designing fields, and planning layouts.

items:
Q1: Find perimeter of a rectangle of length 12 cm and breadth 8 cm. 
Ans: 2 × (12 + 8) = 40 cm.

Q2: Find area of a square plot of side 25 m. 
Ans: 25² = 625 m².

Q3: Find circumference of a circle of radius 7 cm (π = 22/7). 
Ans: 2 × 22/7 × 7 = 44 cm.

Q4: Find area of a triangle with base 10 cm and height 12 cm. 
Ans: 1/2 × 10 × 12 = 60 cm².

title: Heat
subject: Science
description: Learn about heat, temperature, transfer of heat, and applications in daily life.

content.caption: Heat flows from hot body to cold body.

content.text: Heat is a form of energy that makes substances hot or cold. It flows from a hotter object to a colder one until equilibrium is reached.
Temperature measures how hot or cold an object is. It is measured using a thermometer. Common units are Celsius (°C), Fahrenheit (°F), and Kelvin (K).
There are three modes of heat transfer: Conduction (heat through solids), Convection (heat in liquids and gases), and Radiation (heat without medium, e.g., Sun).
Materials like metals are good conductors of heat, while wood and plastic are poor conductors (insulators).
Heat transfer is used in cooking, thermos flasks, designing houses, and industrial processes.

items:
Q1: What is the SI unit of temperature? 
Ans: Kelvin (K).

Q2: Name the three methods of heat transfer. 
Ans: Conduction, Convection, Radiation.

Q3: Why are cooking utensils made of metal but handles made of wood? 
Ans: Metals are good conductors of heat, wood is an insulator.

Q4: Give one example of radiation. 
Ans: Heat received from the Sun.

title: Acids, Bases and Salts
subject: Science
description: Learn about acids, bases, and salts, their properties, and uses.

content.caption: Litmus paper is used to test acids and bases.

content.text: Substances are classified as acids, bases, or salts depending on their chemical nature. They are important in daily life, food, and industry.
Acids taste sour and turn blue litmus red. Examples: Hydrochloric acid (HCl), Sulphuric acid (H₂SO₄), Citric acid in lemon.
Bases taste bitter, feel soapy, and turn red litmus blue. Examples: Sodium hydroxide (NaOH), Calcium hydroxide (Ca(OH)₂).
Salts are formed when acids react with bases (neutralization). Example: NaOH + HCl → NaCl + H₂O.
Indicators like litmus, turmeric, and phenolphthalein help identify acids and bases.
Acids and bases are used in food preservation, cleaning agents, medicine, and fertilizers.

items:
Q1: What happens to blue litmus when dipped in acid? 
Ans: It turns red.

Q2: Give one example each of natural acid and base. 
Ans: Citric acid (acid), Baking soda (base).

Q3: What is neutralization reaction? 
Ans: Reaction between acid and base to form salt and water.

Q4: Why is turmeric used as an indicator? 
Ans: It turns red in bases but remains yellow in acids.

title: Comparing Quantities
subject: Maths
description: Learn how to compare quantities using ratios, percentages, profit and loss, and simple interest.

content.caption: Percentages are widely used for comparing quantities.

content.text: Comparing quantities is important in everyday life for discounts, interest rates, profit/loss, and percentages.
A ratio compares two quantities. A proportion is when two ratios are equal. Example: 2:3 = 4:6.
Percentage means 'per hundred'. Example: 45% = 45/100. Used in marks, discounts, and statistics.
Profit = Selling Price – Cost Price. Loss = Cost Price – Selling Price. Profit% = (Profit/CP)×100.
SI = (P × R × T)/100, where P = Principal, R = Rate, T = Time (years).

items:
Q2: A shopkeeper buys a pen for ₹50 and sells it for ₹65. Find profit%.
Ans: Profit = 15; Profit% = (15/50)×100 = 30%.

Q4: If 5 kg rice costs ₹250, what is the cost of 8 kg?
Ans: 250/5 = 50 per kg → 50×8 = ₹400.

title: Mensuration
subject: Maths
description: Learn formulas for surface area and volume of 3D solids and solve real-life problems.

content.caption: Mensuration includes surface areas and volumes of solids.

content.text: Mensuration in Grade 8 extends to 3D figures, focusing on surface area and volume of cubes, cuboids, cylinders, cones, and spheres.
Formulas: Cube = 6a², Cuboid = 2(lb + bh + hl), Cylinder = 2πr(h + r), Sphere = 4πr², Cone = πr(l + r).
Formulas: Cube = a³, Cuboid = l×b×h, Cylinder = πr²h, Sphere = (4/3)πr³, Cone = (1/3)πr²h.
Surface area is used in painting walls and wrapping gifts. Volume is used in finding storage capacity of tanks or boxes.
Surface area → square units (cm², m²). Volume → cubic units (cm³, m³).

items:
Q1: Find volume of a cube of side 7 cm. 
Ans: 7³ = 343 cm³.

Q2: Find CSA of cylinder with r = 5 cm, h = 10 cm (π=3.14).
Ans: 2πrh = 2×3.14×5×10 = 314 cm².

Q3: A cone has r=3 cm, h=4 cm. Find volume. 
Ans: (1/3)πr²h = (1/3)×3.14×9×4 = 37.68 cm³.

Q4: A spherical ball has radius 14 cm. Find its surface area.
Ans: 4πr² = 4×3.14×196 = 2464.64 cm².

title: Microorganisms: Friend and Foe
subject: Science
description: Learn about microorganisms, their beneficial and harmful effects, and their applications.

content.caption: Microorganisms are found everywhere around us.

content.text: Microorganisms are tiny living organisms not visible to the naked eye. They include bacteria, fungi, protozoa, algae, and viruses.
Used in making curd, bread, antibiotics, and alcohol. Example: Lactobacillus bacteria help in curd formation.
Cause diseases like tuberculosis, cholera, malaria. They also spoil food and damage crops.
Used in medicine (antibiotics, vaccines), agriculture (biofertilizers), and waste management.
Microorganisms spoil food. Preservation methods: salting, refrigeration, canning, and chemical preservatives.

items:
Q1: Name two useful and two harmful microorganisms. 
Ans: Useful – Lactobacillus, Penicillium; Harmful – Plasmodium, Salmonella.

Q2: Which microorganism is used in alcohol production? 
Ans: Yeast.

Q3: State one method of food preservation. 
Ans: Refrigeration.

Q4: Name a disease caused by protozoa. 
Ans: Malaria.

title: Sound
subject: Science
description: Learn about production, propagation, characteristics, and applications of sound.

content.caption: Sound travels as longitudinal waves.

content.text: Sound is produced by vibrations of objects. Example: vibrating strings of guitar.
Sound travels as longitudinal waves through a medium like air, water, or solids but not through vacuum.
Pitch (depends on frequency), Loudness (depends on amplitude), Quality (depends on waveform).
Voice is produced in larynx due to vibration of vocal cords. The human ear detects sound frequencies roughly between 20 Hz to 20,000 Hz.
Used in communication, music, medical field (ultrasound), and echolocation in animals.

items:
Q1: What is the SI unit of frequency? 
Ans: Hertz (Hz).

Q2: Why can’t sound travel through vacuum? 
Ans: Because there are no particles to carry vibrations.

Q3: Name three characteristics of sound. 
Ans: Pitch, Loudness, Quality.

Q4: Which range of sound can humans hear? 
Ans: 20 Hz – 20,000 Hz.

title: Linear Equations in Two Variables
subject: Maths
description: Learn how to represent and solve linear equations in two variables using algebraic and graphical methods.

content.caption: Linear equations in two variables represent straight lines.

content.text: A linear equation in two variables has the form ax + by + c = 0. Its solution is a pair of values (x, y) that satisfies the equation.
Each linear equation represents a straight line on a graph. Solutions are points lying on the line.
Substitution, Elimination, and Cross-Multiplication methods are used to solve pairs of linear equations.
Used in word problems involving age, mixtures, distance-time, and financial planning.
Two lines may intersect (unique solution), be parallel (no solution), or coincide (infinitely many solutions).

items:
Q1: Solve: x + y = 10, x – y = 4. 
Ans: Adding → 2x=14 → x=7, y=3.

Q2: Write equation of line passing through (0,2) with slope 1. 
Ans: y = x + 2.

title: Surface Areas and Volumes
subject: Maths
description: Learn formulas for surface areas and volumes of solid figures and solve practical problems.

content.caption: Solids have surface area and volume.

content.text: Surface area measures outer covering; volume measures space inside. Important for storage, construction, and packaging.
Complex solids are solved by breaking into basic shapes. Example: Ice-cream cone = cone + hemisphere.
Used in designing containers, storage tanks, packaging, and construction works.

items:
Q1: Find volume of a sphere of radius 7 cm. 
Ans: (4/3)π(7³)=1436.76 cm³.

Q2: A cuboid has l=10 cm, b=8 cm, h=6 cm. Find its surface area.
Ans: 2(lb+bh+hl)=2(80+48+60)=376 cm².

Q3: CSA of a cylinder with r=7 cm, h=14 cm (π=22/7). 
Ans: 2πrh=2×22/7×7×14=616 cm².

title: Matter in Our Surroundings
subject: Science
description: Learn about matter, its states, properties, and interconversion.

content.caption: Matter exists in solid, liquid, and gaseous states.

content.text: Matter is anything that occupies space and has mass. It exists mainly in solid, liquid, and gaseous states.
Particles are very small, have space between them, are constantly moving, and attract each other.
Solids have fixed shape, liquids flow and take container’s shape, gases have neither definite shape nor volume.
Matter changes state on heating or cooling. Example: Ice → Water → Steam. Process involves melting, evaporation, condensation, sublimation.
Used in refrigeration, air conditioning, cooking, and industry.

items:
Q1: Define matter. 
Ans: Anything that has mass and occupies space.

Q2: Name three characteristics of particles of matter. 
Ans: Small size, movement, interparticle space.

Q3: What is sublimation? 
Ans: Change of solid directly into gas (e.g., camphor, dry ice).

Q4: Why do solids have definite shape? 
Ans: Because particles are tightly packed.

title: Work and Energy
subject: Science
description: Learn the concept of work, energy, their forms, and the law of conservation of energy.

content.caption: Work is done when force displaces an object.

content.text: Work is done when a force is applied on an object and the object gets displaced in the direction of force. Work = Force × Displacement × cosθ.
If displacement is in direction of force → positive work. If opposite → negative work.
Energy is the capacity to do work. Two main forms: Kinetic Energy (due to motion) and Potential Energy (due to position).
The work done on an object is equal to the change in its kinetic energy.
Energy can neither be created nor destroyed; it only changes from one form to another.
Used in machines, electricity generation, hydroelectric power, and daily activities.

items:
Q1: When is work said to be done? 
Ans: When force is applied and the body is displaced in the direction of force.

Q2: Write the formula for kinetic energy.
